intro: Phoradendron calyculatum var. gonzalezii, commonly known as the Mexican mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in Mexico. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually opposite and dark green in color. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers, followed by small, fleshy berries that are a food source for birds. It is part of the Vitaceae family and is characterized by its ability to derive some of its nutrients from its host through specialized roots. Its ecological role includes supporting bird populations that disperse its seeds.
